name: Ren√© Descartes
bio: A French philosopher, mathematician, and scientist, often regarded as the father of modern philosophy.

arguments.title: Cogito, ergo sum
arguments.importance: Foundation for modern Western philosophy and the concept of self-awareness.
arguments.context: Responded to skepticism about the external world.

influence: His work laid the groundwork for rationalism and influenced subsequent philosophers like Spinoza and Leibniz.

name: Immanuel Kant
bio: A German philosopher who is a central figure in modern philosophy.
works: Groundwork for the Metaphysics of Morals

arguments.title: Categorical Imperative
arguments.description: Act only according to that maxim whereby you can, at the same time, will that it should become a universal law.
arguments.context: Responded to moral relativism and consequentialist theories.
arguments.influence: Influenced deontological ethical theories and human rights discourse.

influence: His critical philosophy bridged rationalism and empiricism, influencing German Idealism and contemporary philosophy.

name: Aristotle
bio: An ancient Greek philosopher and polymath, student of Plato and teacher of Alexander the Great.

arguments.title: Golden Mean
arguments.description: Virtue lies between two extremes of excess and deficiency.
arguments.context: Responded to moral absolutism and hedonism.
arguments.influence: Influenced subsequent ethical theories and character education.

influence: His works laid the foundation for Western philosophy and science, influencing countless scholars through the centuries.

name: Plato
bio: An ancient Greek philosopher, student of Socrates, and teacher of Aristotle.

arguments.title: Theory of Forms
arguments.description: Non-material abstract forms, and not the material world, possess the highest and most fundamental kind of reality.
arguments.context: Responded to the problem of universals and the nature of reality.
arguments.influence: Influenced Neoplatonism, Christian theology, and modern philosophical realism.

influence: Plato's ideas have shaped Western thought, politics, and education for over two millennia.
